content:
Let XXX be a topological space and S∙(X)S_{\bullet}(X)S∙​(X) its singular simplicial set. The set S0(X)S_0(X)S0​(X) can be identified with the set of points of XXX and S1(X)S_1(X)S1​(X) can be identified with the set of paths in XXX. Let σ,σ′∈S1(X)\sigma,\sigma'\in S_1(X)σ,σ′∈S1​(X) be two loops based at x∈Xx\in Xx∈X. Why is a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′ the same thing as a 2-simplex τ∈S2(X)\tau\in S_2(X)τ∈S2​(X) with the faces d0(τ)=s0(x)d_0(\tau)=s_0(x)d0​(τ)=s0​(x), d1(τ)=σd_1(\tau)=\sigmad1​(τ)=σ, and d2(τ)=σ′d_2(\tau)=\sigma'd2​(τ)=σ′?

Unwinding the definitions, s0(x)s_0(x)s0​(x) is the map on the line that is constant xxx. Hence such a τ\tauτ is given by a function f ⁣:{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→Xf\colon \{(x,y)\in\mathbb R^1\mid 0\leq x\leq 1\text{ and }y\leq x\}\to Xf:{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→X such that f(0,−)=σf(0,-)=\sigmaf(0,−)=σ, f(−,1)=σ′f(-,1)=\sigma'f(−,1)=σ′, and f(x,x)=xf(x,x)=xf(x,x)=x. Hence (I think) it is a homotopy from σ′∘σ\sigma'\circ \sigmaσ′∘σ to the constant path (is it?). But why is this the same as a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′?

Leopold Schlicht said:

Let XXX be a topological space and S∙(X)S_{\bullet}(X)S∙​(X) its singular simplicial set. The set S0(X)S_0(X)S0​(X) can be identified with the set of points of XXX and S1(X)S_1(X)S1​(X) can be identified with the set of paths in XXX. Let σ,σ′∈S1(X)\sigma,\sigma'\in S_1(X)σ,σ′∈S1​(X) be two loops based at x∈Xx\in Xx∈X. Why is a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′ the same thing as a 2-simplex τ∈S2(X)\tau\in S_2(X)τ∈S2​(X) with the faces d0(τ)=s0(x)d_0(\tau)=s_0(x)d0​(τ)=s0​(x), d1(τ)=σd_1(\tau)=\sigmad1​(τ)=σ, and d2(τ)=σ′d_2(\tau)=\sigma'd2​(τ)=σ′?

Calling them "the same thing" is an exaggeration. But you can turn any such 2-simplex into a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′, and you can also turn any such homotopy into such a 2-simplex. (I'm not going to claim there's a unique way, but there's probably some widely used standard way.)

Unwinding the definitions, s0(x)s_0(x)s0​(x) is the map on the line that is constant xxx. Hence such a τ\tauτ is given by a function f ⁣:{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→Xf\colon \{(x,y)\in\mathbb R^1\mid 0\leq x\leq 1\text{ and }y\leq x\}\to Xf:{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→X such that f(0,−)=σf(0,-)=\sigmaf(0,−)=σ, f(−,1)=σ′f(-,1)=\sigma'f(−,1)=σ′, and f(x,x)=xf(x,x)=xf(x,x)=x. Hence (I think) it is a homotopy from σ′∘σ\sigma'\circ \sigmaσ′∘σ to the constant path (is it?). But why is this the same as a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′?

A homotopy from σ′∘σ\sigma'\circ \sigmaσ′∘σ to the constant path gives you a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to (σ′)−1(\sigma')^{-1}(σ′)−1. So, I think you've made some orientation mistake, which is really easy to do in this game.

Leopold Schlicht said:

Unwinding the definitions, s0(x)s_0(x)s0​(x) is the map on the line that is constant xxx. Hence such a τ\tauτ is given by a function f ⁣:{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→Xf\colon \{(x,y)\in\mathbb R^1\mid 0\leq x\leq 1\text{ and }y\leq x\}\to Xf:{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→X such that f(0,−)=σf(0,-)=\sigmaf(0,−)=σ, f(−,1)=σ′f(-,1)=\sigma'f(−,1)=σ′, and f(x,x)=xf(x,x)=xf(x,x)=x. Hence (I think) it is a homotopy from σ′∘σ\sigma'\circ \sigmaσ′∘σ to the constant path (is it?). But why is this the same as a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′?

These should be f(0,−)=σ′f(0,-) = \sigma'f(0,−)=σ′, f(t,t)=σ(t)f(t, t) = \sigma(t)f(t,t)=σ(t), f(t,1)=xf(t, 1) = xf(t,1)=x. (I renamed your coordinates on ∣Δ2∣|\Delta^2|∣Δ2∣ because you already have something else called xxx.)

Draw a triangle with vertices 0, 1, 2 - that's your 2-simplex τ\tauτ.

Draw a σ\sigmaσ on the edge from 0 to 2 - that's the edge not containing 1, so it's d1(τ)d_1(\tau)d1​(τ).

Draw a σ′\sigma'σ′ on the edge from 0 to 1 - that's the edge not containing 2, so it's d2(τ)d_2(\tau)d2​(τ).

For your triangle to describe a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′, the edge from 1 to 2 should be a constant path.
and in these coordinates 0 is at (0, 0), 1 is at (1, 0), 2 is at (1, 1)

I think a sequence of homeomorphisms ∣Δ2∣≅D2≅[0,1]×[0,1]|\Delta^2| \cong D^2\cong [0,1]\times [0,1]∣Δ2∣≅D2≅[0,1]×[0,1] like in the picture below should do the trick

image.png

You can also roundabout this through basic quasicategorical babble. As John was saying, a homotopy from f to g corresponds to a 2-simplex H that looks like this:
image.png

Your τ\tauτ however witnesses that s0(x)s_0(x)s0​(x) serves as a composite for σ′∘σ\sigma'\circ\sigmaσ′∘σ. Another possibility is the path concatenation σ′⋆σ\sigma'\star\sigmaσ′⋆σ, but any such composites are homotopic (in the quasicategorical sense). Then they're homotopic, but quasicategorical homotopy <-> topological homotopy in Sing(X)Sing(X)Sing(X).

Thanks all! But I still don't get it.

Daniel Teixeira said:

As John was saying, a homotopy from f to g corresponds to a 2-simplex H that looks like this:
image.png

That's precisely the question I'm asking. Why is a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′ the same as a triangle with edges σ\sigmaσ, σ′\sigma'σ′, and s0(x)s_0(x)s0​(x)?

Your τ\tauτ however witnesses that s0(x)s_0(x)s0​(x) serves as a composite for σ′∘σ\sigma'\circ\sigmaσ′∘σ. Another possibility is the path concatenation σ′⋆σ\sigma'\star\sigmaσ′⋆σ, but any such composites are homotopic (in the quasicategorical sense). Then they're homotopic, but quasicategorical homotopy <-> topological homotopy in Sing(X)Sing(X)Sing(X).

Unfortunately that's too handwavy for me. :sweat_smile:

Daniel Teixeira said:

I think a sequence of homeomorphisms ∣Δ2∣≅D2≅[0,1]×[0,1]|\Delta^2| \cong D^2\cong [0,1]\times [0,1]∣Δ2∣≅D2≅[0,1]×[0,1] like in the picture below should do the trick

image.png

Of course intuitively that makes sense, but I don't know how to translate this into mathematics: how to formally write down the bijection between the "triangle homotopies" {(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→X\{(x,y)\in\mathbb R^1\mid 0\leq x\leq 1\text{ and }y\leq x\}\to X{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→X and "square homotopies" [0,1]×[0,1]→X[0,1]\times[0,1]\to X[0,1]×[0,1]→X? I'm pretty sure it isn't enough to just precompose with any homeomorphism {(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}≅[0,1]×[0,1]\{(x,y)\in\mathbb R^1\mid 0\leq x\leq 1\text{ and }y\leq x\}\cong [0,1]\times [0,1]{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}≅[0,1]×[0,1], as you seem to suggest.

You should precompose with a map F:[0,1]×[0,1]→{ (x,y)∣0≤y≤x≤1 }F : [0,1] \times [0,1] \to \{\,(x,y) \mid 0 \le y \le x \le 1\,\}F:[0,1]×[0,1]→{(x,y)∣0≤y≤x≤1} that satisfies the right boundary conditions: F(0,u)=(0,0)F(0,u) = (0, 0)F(0,u)=(0,0) for all uuu, F(1,u)F(1, u)F(1,u) lies on the edge (1,∗)(1, *)(1,∗) for all uuu, F(t,0)=(t,0)F(t, 0) = (t, 0)F(t,0)=(t,0), F(t,1)=(t,t)F(t, 1) = (t, t)F(t,1)=(t,t). For example, F(t,u)=(t,tu)F(t, u) = (t, tu)F(t,u)=(t,tu).

This isn't even a homeomorphism! :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes: Thanks!
Does this yield a bijection between "triangle homotopies" and "square homotopies" or something a bit weaker?
By the way, when you're a topologist you look at this:

and you see the top left edge is the path σ\sigmaσ, while the bottom edge is the path σ′\sigma'σ′, and the right edge is a constant path...

... so you know that if you slide the top left edge down to the bottom edge - keeping its left endpoint fixed while sliding its right endpoint down the constant path s0(x)s_0(x)s0​(x) - you get a homotopy from σ\sigmaσ to σ′\sigma'σ′.

You don't think consciously about formulas for maps from the square to the triangle. You just think "here is a way to morph the path σ\sigmaσ to the path σ′\sigma'σ′ while keeping both its endpoints fixed - so, a homotopy!"
When you're getting started in topology you write down a bunch of formulas for maps, but this eventually becomes too slow: it's enough to know you could.

How would one formulate precisely the statement that there is a "bijection" or "correspondence" between "triangle homotopies" {(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→X\{(x,y)\in\mathbb R^1\mid 0\leq x\leq 1\text{ and }y\leq x\}\to X{(x,y)∈R1∣0≤x≤1 and y≤x}→X and "square homotopies" [0,1]×[0,1]→X[0,1]\times[0,1]\to X[0,1]×[0,1]→X? The map that sends each triangle homotopy τ\tauτ to F∘τF\circ \tauF∘τ is not surjective I guess, since FFF is not injective.

The "triangle homotopies" and "square homotopies" aren't just maps of those types, they have to satisfy certain boundary conditions. In particular, they have to be constant on certain subsets of the triangle/square (one edge of the triangle, and two opposite edges of the square); that means they correspond uniquely to maps out of the quotients by those subsets. The map FFF induces a homeomorphism of those quotients, so the original "triangle homotopies" and "square homotopies" are in fact in bijection.

However, it's not necessarily a great idea to attach too much significance to this specific bijection because the map FFF was kind of arbitrarily chosen. The main point is that two paths are "triangularly homotopic" if and only if they are "squarely homotopic".
Thanks, that's very helpful!

Reid Barton said:

The "triangle homotopies" and "square homotopies" aren't just maps of those types, they have to satisfy certain boundary conditions. In particular, they have to be constant on certain subsets of the triangle/square (one edge of the triangle, and two opposite edges of the square) [...]

Actually, why does a homotopy H ⁣:[0,1]×[0,1]→XH\colon [0,1]\times [0,1]\to XH:[0,1]×[0,1]→X from a loop σ\sigmaσ to a loop σ′\sigma'σ′ need to be constant on two opposite edges of the square? The only conditions I am aware of are H(−,0)=σH(-,0)=\sigmaH(−,0)=σ and H(−,1)=σ′H(-,1)=\sigma'H(−,1)=σ′. There seem to be no conditions on the edges (0,−)(0,-)(0,−) and (1,−)(1,-)(1,−).
Good question!
This is what people mean when they talk about a homotopy between paths, even if sometimes they forget to say it.

Leopold Schlicht said:

Actually, why does a homotopy H ⁣:[0,1]×[0,1]→XH\colon [0,1]\times [0,1]\to XH:[0,1]×[0,1]→X from a loop σ\sigmaσ to a loop σ′\sigma'σ′ need to be constant on two opposite edges of the square? The only considtions I am aware of are H(−,0)=σH(-,0)=\sigmaH(−,0)=σ and H(−,1)=σ′H(-,1)=\sigma'H(−,1)=σ′. There seem to be no conditions on the edges (0,−)(0,-)(0,−) and (1,−)(1,-)(1,−).

The definition you're considering is that of a general homotopy. There is a notion of path homotopy with fixed endpoints. The fundamental group would be totally uninteresting if we used the standard definition of homotopy rather than the notion of path homotopy with fixed endpoints.

I don't think they really have to be constant, but they definitely have to be equal to each other all the way down, otherwise you could take apart one loop, drag it along itself and the other, and join it, making all loops homotopic to each other!

For the purpose of defining the fundamental group you really do want them to be constant--if you just ask for a homotopy through loops, the basepoint could trace out a nontrivial loop γ\gammaγ and then you end up identifying two loops that are conjugates by γ\gammaγ.
Because if you go around the square one way you have σ\sigmaσ then γ\gammaγ, but the other way you have γ\gammaγ then σ′\sigma'σ′.
... and in any case fixed endpoints is what you need for the fundamental groupoid, and if you obtain the fundamental group from the fundamental groupoid it's what you get.
Ah, I see, thanks so much! Hence in this case the right wikipedia page to look at is Path (topology) and not Homotopy. :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
